awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Integrated Online Coordinated Routing and Decentralized Control for Connected Vehicle Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Traffic congestion jeopardizes the function of urban transportation systems and has a growing negative effect on the health of urban economies.  It also increases air pollution with numerous negative health impacts on our citizenry.  A promising solution to alleviating traffic congestion is to establish coordinated driving mechanisms.  This is enabled by recent connected or even autonomous vehicle technologies and advanced onboard computing facilities.  However, engineers who design such mechanisms are still lacking scientific knowledge and effective tools that can be proven as efficient and reliable for use by the general public.  The goal of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) program award is to develop innovative approaches to the coordination of connected vehicle drivers- online route choices.  This will be done by exploiting emerging information and computing technologies equipped in connected transportation infrastructure. This approache will improve transportation system mobility, safety, and environmental sustainability without sacrificing the interests of the individual vehicles. This research will deepen our understanding of the competition among vehicles on limited traffic resources.  It should also reveal the impacts of the decisions of individual vehicles on traffic congestion, and offer a new paradigm of real-time traffic control.
 
The specific research objectives of this CAREER project are: (a) developing coordinated mechanisms for drivers - route choices to mitigate over-competition; (b) engineering collective effects of drivers - decisions to improve system-level performance; and (c) implementing the coordinated routing mechanisms and decentralized traffic control in an online environment.  If successful, this project will lead to: (1) game-theory based modeling, analysis, and design techniques for coordinated routing mechanisms; (2) innovative methods for integrating decentralized control into individual routing decisions via intentional information perturbation techniques; and (3) better understanding of convergence, efficiency and robustness of distributed algorithms for decentralized congestion control. The reseach approaches include: (a) using game theory, optimization, and traffic dynamics to design and analyze coordination mechanisms; (b) using equilibrium analysis, price of anarchy, bounded rationality, and decentralized control for the study of collective effects; and (c) developing distributed algorithms for implementation and carrying out a theoretical analysis of these algorithms. This project will involve underrepresented K-12 students, undergraduate and graduate college students in numerous research tasks, and disseminate research findings through multiple channels, such as national/international workshops and conferences, as well as journal publications.

por.por_cntn:
Connected (and Autonomous) Vehicles (CVs and CAVs) open up the possibility to manipulate individual CAVs' real-time route or other driving decisions to achieve collective and desired system effects in improving traffic safety, mobility, and sustainability. This CAREER project seeks to initiate decentralized traffic management through artfully coordinating online individual vehicles' route choices and strategic information provision to relieve traffic congestion and enhance the environmental sustainability of transportation systems. Along with the research activities, we want to educate the next-generation workforce through interdisciplinary and project-based education, which promotes integrative research, combining transportation engineering with the areas of operations research, data sciences, control, and computer sciences. The outreach activities will encourage education and research opportunities for underrepresented K-12 students, college students, and professionals in intelligent transportation systems.

Significant outcomes by achieving the three-fold objectives during 2016-2023 are summarized as follows.  

Intellectual merits:

This CAREER project has successfully established the theoretical and methodology foundations (see Figure 1) for Real-Time Distributed and Coordinated Routing Mechanisms (CRM). Through collective efforts in twelve journal papers, the project generated the following significant methodologies, which enable designing online coordinated routing mechanisms, engineering collective route choice effect, and leveraging distributed computation resources.  

1. Modeling: invented the snapshot equilibrium routing mechanisms (a route choice resolution among a group of travelers) based on atomic game theories in three possible schemes: pure/mixed strategy Nash game, correlated game to guide travelers' real-time route choices, aiming to mitigate congestion without over-sacrificing individual travelers' trip interests. The existence of equilibrium under each game model was mathematically proved. To be noted,  previous traffic equilibrium studies are based on nonatomic game theories. Rather than guiding individual travelers ' real-time route choices, they often aim to generate traffic flow assignment solutions for long-term traffic planning or network design.  

2. Solution: introduced distributed optimization and algorithms (such as) to solve the game models so that we can coordinate individual travelers' real-time routing decisions using their portable computation resources. The convergence of each algorithm is mathematically proved. Most previous studies focus on independent best response or centralized system-optimal approaches. The robustness and resilience of the distribution against communication failures were also investigated theoretically.

3. Optimality: introduced information perturbation (IP) approach and theories ("travel time toll") to further push snapshot equilibrium routing decisions toward system optimal without intervening individual travelers' route choices. It avoids the extra cost and differs from existing congestion pricing schemes.   

4. Scalability: introduced routing coordinated potential concepts and theories, which facilitate applying AI technology to build routing coordination coalitions among travelers and solve the scalability issue to implement the CRM in a big city.

5. Extension: extended the ideas of CRM to coordinate real-time parking, ridesharing decisions, and network traffic signal control to achieve coordinated traffic/driving control for traffic congestion mitigation.

This project opened up a new line of traffic congestion management on a network and other infrastructures such as parking lots and EV charging stations; helped better understanding the interaction between individual vehicles' decisions and overall system performance in traffic-relevant congestion; and introduced a new concept of real-time traffic control by employing emerging informative transportation environment and distributed computational resources of smart transportation facilities.

Broader Impact:

The success of this project will significantly relieve traffic congestion, hence, save valuable time/traffic dollars for millions of drivers, and enhance the mobility and environmental sustainability of modern transportation systems.

The development of this scientific foundation involved highly interdisciplinary research, combining theories and techniques from multidisciplinary areas: traffic flow theory, game theory, discrete choice models, queue theory, distributed algorithm design, and optimization. Therefore, it will spread a broader impact to other disciplines beyond transportation, such as optimization, control, and computer sciences.

The research carried out in this project have led to twelve journal articles published in top-tier journals in transportation, such as Transporation Research Part B: Methodological, Transporation Research Part C: Emerging Technologies, IEEE Transactions on ITS, along with other journal articles under review and many refereed conference papers published and presented in significant transportation conferences. The project has partially supported seven Ph.D. students (one of them is female). One Ph.D. student' dissertation received a COTA dissertation award: third place. One Ph.D. won the FAV Summit Student Poster Award: Third Place. One student won Department Ken Courage Award. The PI and her Ph.D. students have presented the research findings at many university, government, and industry seminars (invited talks), workshops, and conferences.

Moreover, the PI made a webinar for students in the Bush School, Interlake High School, and Newport High School in Seattle, WA, to support their programs on connecting (girls) with Professionals. The PI created a new lecture for the two classes she taught to have students understand how the learned traffic equilibrium and optimization help mitigate traffic congestion. Those project activities expose students to cutting-edge emerging technologies and sparked students' interest in pursuing an education or career in STEM.
